replies.context: It doesn't matter: knowledge is priceless.
Here's a bit of knowledge, you pay for it.
The value of knowledge is relegated to where you dip your cup.

If i interpret your phrase "where you dip your cup" correctly, I disagree: all knowledge, whether immediately useful or not, whether relevant or irrelevant to one's field(s) of interest, is invaluable. In my opinion, only the dead are incurious.
There is temporal knowledge and there is eternal knowledge, you may already have chosen which you esteem.

I wasn't aware the two are mutually exclusive, O Obtuse One. Thank you for the enlightenment.

So, riddle me this: which of God's creations wanders, wonders, and marvels at His universe? I'll answer for you: the human mind.

Ciao, senza cervello.

So, then you agree eternal knowledge is available and is "relevant" and "invaluable," next, the understanding that the temporal knowledge will be disposed of at some time in the future and the more valuable eternal knowledge will remain.

Ciao, ancora.

I do not agree, my adorably naïve  little dewdrop. I never said that. Your argument is specious, at best, ridiculous, at worst.

I believe in a multiverse that may or may not be "eternal." However, if it is, indeed, the "eternity" of which you write, it doesn't negate all other knowledge. If it did, there would be a problem: with the exception of adherents of predestination, knowledge of our past sins and indiscretions, as well as of our good deeds and contributions to the betterment of mankind, allegedly forms the basis of the eternal fate of our souls.

So, while we're talking about knowledge in general, let's get more specific and bring God into the discussion. Speaking from a Catholic point of view—my native faith, and the only one of which I have any real knowledge—by definition, a sin is a deliberate offense against one or more of God's laws. He gave us free will, so we choose when—if ever—to sin, we choose when—if ever—to do good, and we must have knowledge of our sins in order to be judged for them. For each of us, that knowledge, while "temporal" in origin, must be eternal in God's mind and ours. After all, would a just God punish us without letting us know why? If you agree that all knowledge ultimately comes from God, you must admit temporal and eternal knowledge become the same when one dies. In other words, temporal knowledge and eternal knowledge are essentially identical, and are not mutually exclusive.

So, 'nuff said. I've made my point.

Arrogance is not a conducive vehicle to propagate reason. Socrates, Plato and Aristotle were great thinkers considering all before them, and they had to reason in the Areopagus and remain credible amongst their peers. You apparently have some conservative thinking, with maturation and meekness you could acquire credibility. Aim for the heart, not from the ego.

*sigh* 

Throwing around the names of long-dead philosophers—ones every school child knows—and that of a rock does not make you an intellectual. It makes you a rock-and-philosophers' names dropper. While I have a passing familiarity with the philosophers you mentioned, as a mathematician, the only ancient Greeks in whom I'm interested are Pythagoras, Euclid, Archimedes, and Eratosthenes 

I'm 68 years old, and as mature as I'm ever gonna get, but thank you for your heartfelt concern. As for "meekness," it's overrated, and certainly not a virtue. Meek people get walked on by others. I'm quite self-confident, frequently pedantic, almost always sarcastic, and often arrogant, because I usually know what I'm talking about, or at the very least have strong, well-reasoned opinions.

My patience with those who try to sway me by simply repeating the same sophistic "argument" is nil. Such behavior is reminiscent of the saying, "The definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results." (No, Einstein didn't say it; nor did Mark Twain or Ben Franklin: it probably originated with a 1981 Narcotics Anonymous pamphlet.)

In my opinion, I've made my point, and you haven't made yours to my satisfaction. Since neither of us is ever likely to change the other's mind, you have nothing more to say that could possibly interest me. Having said that, reply all you want to: I've decided to mute you rather than continue this circular discussion.

Could the JWST potentially find that '9th' planet that may be out there? There's evidence to suggest that it's there, but we've yet to find it, so we can't say for sure.

For perspective on a scale model of the universe somebody made, Neptune was a quarter mile from the sun, and this 9th planet would be 18 miles away to scale. This planet, if it is indeed one and there's not some other explanation which is entirely possible, would be a seemingly impossible distance from the sun.

replies.context: I don't think it's useful for that, but who knows. If planet 9 puts out IR heat, the telescope can see it.
If there is a 9th it is believed to be an ice giant like Neptune so it would glow in infrared. But like you said it would be much further away and we’d have no idea where to look for it.

JWST is best for imaging things we already know are at a certain location.  Its narrow field of view is like looking through a very narrow drinking straw, unless you know where to point it you'll spend a lifetime trying to find something.
